newMoon.name: New Moon
newMoon.info: Illumination: 0%; invisible from Earth; marks start of lunar cycle.
newMoon.history: From Sumerian temple rites to Babylonian calendars, the New Moon (called â€œhilalâ€ in Arabic) kicked off each lunar month. In ancient Israel, it was a state holiday (Rosh á¸¤odesh) with special sacrifices, and in East Asia it marked the start of the lunar New Year festival.
newMoon.spiritual: Considered the ultimate blank slateâ€”rituals involve meditative intention-setting, planting literal seeds, and drawing sigils. In modern witchcraft you might brew a â€œnew moon teaâ€ with mugwort and rosemary to amplify your goals.
newMoon.astronomy: Occurs at exact conjunction when the Moon and Sun share ecliptic longitude. No part of the lunar surface is illuminated except during a solar eclipse. Synodic cycle is ~29.53 days.

faqs.a: At conjunction the Moonâ€™s dark side faces us. You only glimpse it during a solar eclipse when it crosses the Sunâ€™s disk.

faqs.q: How often does the New Moon occur?
faqs.a: About every 29.5 daysâ€”the length of a synodic monthâ€”when the Moon returns to conjunction with the Sun.

waxingCrescent.name: Waxing Crescent
waxingCrescent.info: Visible low in western sky after sunset; illumination rising.
waxingCrescent.history: Greco-Roman farmers noted the first sliver to plan spring planting; medieval Islamic astronomers tracked the crescent (â€œhilalâ€) sightings to set Ramadanâ€™s start. In coastal Asia, fishermen read its height to time tides.
waxingCrescent.spiritual: A phase of gestationâ€”common rituals include charging crystals on a windowsill and writing affirmations for growth. Tarot spreads focus on â€œwhatâ€™s sproutingâ€ in your life.
waxingCrescent.astronomy: Visible 1â€“6 days after New Moon; sunlight grows from ~1% up to ~50%. Best seen low in the west just after sunset, often via binoculars if very thin.

faqs.a: Yesâ€”haze, clouds, and low horizon visibility can hide that thin sliver; you need a clear western sky just after sunset.

faqs.q: How long does the Waxing Crescent phase last?
faqs.a: Roughly 3â€“5 days, as the illuminated portion grows from about 1% to nearly 50%.

firstQuarter.name: First Quarter
firstQuarter.info: Rises at midday, sets at midnight; half-lit, good for observation.
firstQuarter.history: On Roman calendars the First Quarter heralded market days; half-moon votive offerings to Luna were found at Pompeiiâ€™s temple of Diana. Indigenous North Americans used it to split winter chores.
firstQuarter.spiritual: Action-packedâ€”rituals focus on cutting ties: burn paper symbols of fear, then bury the ashes. Physically tackle a â€œnext stepâ€ project to honor its dynamic energy.
firstQuarter.astronomy: Occurs at ~90Â° elongation; exactly half the disk is lit. The terminator casts sharp shadowsâ€”ideal for telescopic detailâ€”rises at noon, sets at midnight.

faqs.a: It marks one-quarter of the way through the lunar cycleâ€”not the shape, but the fraction of the cycle completed.

faqs.q: When is the best time to see it?
faqs.a: Itâ€™s highest in the sky around sunset, making the early evening perfect for observation.

waxingGibbous.name: Waxing Gibbous
waxingGibbous.info: High in eastern sky before midnight; approaching fullness.
waxingGibbous.history: Medieval astrologers watched Waxing Gibbous to refine harvest timing; in Celtic lore it was the â€œgreat motherâ€™s swellâ€ used for blessing milking herds.
waxingGibbous.spiritual: A phase of refinementâ€”do a â€œprogress auditâ€ on your New Moon goals. Rituals include moonlit journaling and crystal grids to fine-tune your path.
waxingGibbous.astronomy: Spans ~7â€“13 days after New Moon, illumination from ~51% up to ~99%. Visible afternoon into evening; terminator moves eastward across the lunar surface.

faqs.a: â€œGibbousâ€ comes from Latin for â€œhumpâ€â€”it signifies more than half illuminated but not yet full.
The growing illumination mirrors a build-up toward culmination; mentally you may feel heightened creativity or tension.

fullMoon.name: Full Moon
fullMoon.info: Rises at sunset, sets at sunrise; brightest night of cycle.
fullMoon.history: Harvest Moon festivals in Europe, the Native American â€œCorn Moon,â€ and Vesak in Buddhism all celebrate fullness. Ancient Greeks held â€œKÅ«rios SelÄ“nÄ“â€ dances honoring the light of the goddess.
fullMoon.spiritual: A climax of release and illuminationâ€”popular rituals are moonlit baths with sea salt, writing what you need to let go of, then burning it. People gather in â€œmoon circlesâ€ worldwide.
fullMoon.astronomy: Opposition to the Sun, 100% lit. Rises at sunset, sets at sunrise. If near lunar node, a partial or total lunar eclipse may occur.

faqs.q: When is the next Full Moon?
faqs.a: You can check any lunar calendar or sky-watching app; typically it recurs every 29.5 days.
Folk names like â€œStrawberryâ€ or â€œHunterâ€™sâ€ track seasonal eventsâ€”vital markers in agrarian calendars worldwide.

waningGibbous.name: Waning Gibbous
waningGibbous.info: Visible late at night through dawn; illumination decreasing.
waningGibbous.history: Egyptian priests offered libations to Isis in this phase; Japanese farmers practiced â€œtsuki-miâ€ moon-viewing of the waning glow for harvest thanks.
waningGibbous.spiritual: A time of gratitudeâ€”rituals include â€œthank-youâ€ journaling and sharing blessings in community. Energetically you integrate lessons rather than push forward.
waningGibbous.astronomy: Illumination drops from ~99% to ~51%. Rises after sunset, remains visible through the night into the morning.

faqs.a: A faint glow on the dark portion of the Moon caused by sunlight reflected off Earthâ€”best seen in early waning stages.

faqs.q: How long does Waning Gibbous last?
faqs.a: About 7 days, as illumination falls from nearly full (99%) down to about half (51%).

lastQuarter.name: Last Quarter
lastQuarter.info: Rises at midnight, sets at noon; half-lit opposite first quarter.
lastQuarter.history: Dubbed â€œThird Quarterâ€ by astronomers, many pagan paths honor the Crone archetype here, symbolizing wisdom and the cycleâ€™s closure.
lastQuarter.spiritual: A sovereign pauseâ€”rituals often involve writing regrets, then ceremonially discarding them (burying or releasing to water) to clear karmic slate.
lastQuarter.astronomy: Occurs at ~90Â° elongation past opposition; half the disk lit on the opposite side of First Quarter.

faqs.a: It signifies three-quarters through the cycle, with exactly half the Moon lit on the opposite side of First Quarter.

faqs.q: When is the next New Moon?
faqs.a: Roughly 7 days after Last Quarter, the cycle begins anew.

waningCrescent.name: Waning Crescent
waningCrescent.info: Visible in eastern pre-dawn sky; waning toward new moon.
waningCrescent.history: Called the â€œDark Moonâ€ in folk agriculture, it marked final harvests and soil rest. In Western mystery schools, it was a time of deep inner work.
waningCrescent.spiritual: Ultimate closureâ€”dark moon ceremonies include silent retreats, shadow-work journaling, and tarot readings to face endings.
waningCrescent.astronomy: Visible 26â€“29 days into the cycle; illumination shrinks from ~49% to 0%. Best seen low in the east just before dawn.

faqs.a: Itâ€™s the final visible crescent before conjunction; the rest of the month is in darkness until the New Moon.

faqs.q: How long does Waning Crescent last?
faqs.a: Typically 3â€“4 days before the New Moon, as illumination shrinks from about 25% to 0%.
